description: Sam Ezersky buzzes us in, across and around today’s puzzle
title: Variety: Marching Bands
title_page: Variety: Marching Bands - The New York Times
text:
SUNDAY VARIETY COLUMN — I always think of Spelling Bee, to which I’m addicted, when I think of Sam Ezersky, but Marching Bands is fun too and it’s his first crack at it. This is just my third or fourth attempt at this style of puzzle and I think I’ve got the knack, or at least a consistent approach.
I now work the rows first thing. Since they each have two clues, you can deduce where to enter any answers you’re sure of. So I threw in GERMAN, TENURE, FALLEN and NINETY, ELEVEN PM and “on sale” (whoops! I mean OR LESS) with some confidence, making the bands around a bit easier to piece together.
Any thing I encounter in life (in the puzzle environs and beyond) that references MARY TYLER MOORE is a winner in my book. Her full name hasn’t been in the Times grid yet, according to xwordinfo.com — she’d be such a joyous seed entry for an odd-shaped puzzle (or a Sunday). I also absolutely loved the back and forth overlap of CANAPE and PANACHE, MELTY and WHEAT GERM. The only entry I thought was iffy was AGE LEVEL, but the rest was pure gold.
